label: Special case - Type of, Sort of, Kind of

questions.question: Type of
questions.hint: Used to categorize or classify something into a specific group or category.
answer: What type of music do you like? I'm into classical and jazz.
This is a type of software designed for data analysis.
He prefers a type of exercise that's low-impact, like swimming or yoga.
There are several types of cuisines available at this restaurant, including Italian and Thai.
She collects a type of artwork known for its abstract style.

questions.question: Sort of
questions.hint: Used to express a degree of uncertainty or to describe something that is not exactly one thing but somewhat similar.
answer: It's sort of chilly today; you might need a light jacket.
He's sort of new to the job, so he might need some guidance.
The movie was sort of interesting but not exactly captivating.
This recipe is sort of like the one my grandmother used to make.
She's sort of an expert in the field, though not officially certified.

questions.question: Kind of
questions.hint: Used to indicate a general or approximate description, often expressing something that is not precisely one thing but close to it.
answer: I'm kind of tired today; I didn't sleep well last night.
That restaurant has a kind of rustic charm that's quite appealing.
He's kind of upset about the news, though he's trying to stay calm.
The new policy is kind of confusing, but I'm sure we'll get used to it.
Her dress is kind of similar to the one I saw at the boutique last week.
